{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3389476,"name":"Guilherme","username":"oGuizim","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/o/e9bcb4/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-05-20T17:59:01.443Z","cooked":"

Our shooter we actually using the DutyCycleRange to get de encoder position, but when we change to spare parts, the encoder switch the position and failed the code, so what i can use to substitute the DutyCycleRange, im thinking use the setOffset, but i don’t know how it works. Anyone can help me to understand

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":3,"updated_at":"2024-05-20T17:59:01.443Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":4,"reads":116,"readers_count":115,"score":43.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":466621,"topic_slug":"dutycycleencoder","display_username":"Guilherme","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":62483,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Competitor"},"post_url":"/t/dutycycleencoder/466621/1","custom_user_title":"Competitor","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3389625,"name":"Akash Dubey | Programming Captain 1257","username":"AkeBoss","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/akeboss/{size}/203787_2.png","created_at":"2024-05-20T22:48:21.574Z","cooked":"

The issue with the encoder is that you probably have to re-zero it when you put it on the robot for the first time. Depending on the type of encoder, the process may be different; however, it’s usually a good idea to zero your encoders whenever you put them on for the first time so that you can use spare parts. All this does is set the 0 or start position of the encoder.

Here’s how you can re-zero it if you have a REV through bore encoder connected to a CAN Spark Max.

If you’re only using the velocity data from your shooter encoder, there might be some other issue.
